newsitem.title: USA: Pizzeria Uno settles FTC low-fat ads charges.
newsitem.headline: Pizzeria Uno settles FTC low-fat ads charges.

text.p: Uno Restaurant Corp unit Pizzeria Uno has agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that its thin-crust pizzas are not low in fat, as its advertisements claim, the FTC said Wednesday.
"To settle the charges, the chain has agreed not to misrepresent the existence or amount of fat or any other nutrient or substance in pizzas," an FTC statement said.

The FTC, in its first enforcement over nutrient claims made by a restaurant chain, said Boston-based Uno Restaurant Corp and subsidiaries Pizzeria Uno Corp and Uno Restaurants promoted "Thinzettas" in TV and print commercials as "low fat" whereas six were over acceptable limts for low fat claims, with some containing up to 36 grams of fat per serving.

"Millions of consumers are conscientious about the fat content of their food," FTC Bureau of Consumer Protection chief Jodie Bernstein was quoted as saying, adding "Consumers expect nutrient content claims made for products to be true."
The FTC said the low-fat claim was false and misleading.
The proposed consent agreement does not constitute an admission of a law violation, the FTC said. After 60 days for public comment it can be made final with the force of law.
